problem_prompt: Solve the following problem. If $a\equiv 18\pmod{42}$ and $b\equiv 73\pmod{42}$, then for what integer $n$ in the set $\{100,101,102,\ldots,140,141\}$ is it true that $$a-b\equiv n\pmod{42}~?$$
solution:
Reading all congruences $\pmod{42}$, we have \begin{align*}
a-b &\equiv 18-73 \\
&\equiv -55 \\
&\equiv -55+42+42 \\
&\equiv 29\pmod{42}.
\end{align*}That's great, except we want to find $n$ with $100\leq n<142$.  Therefore we should add copies of 42 until we get into this range: \[29\equiv 29+42\equiv71\pmod{42}.\]That's not large enough. \[71\equiv71+42\equiv113\pmod{42}.\]That is in our range, so $n=\boxed{113}$.
gpt_response:
We have $a\equiv 18\pmod{42}$ and $b\equiv 73\pmod{42}$. 

Therefore, $a-b\equiv 18-73\equiv -55\equiv -55+42 \equiv -13 \equiv 29\pmod{42}$.

So we are looking for an integer $n$ such that $n \equiv 29 \pmod{42}$ and $100 \leq n \leq 141$. 

We can see that the integers in the set $\{100,101,102,\ldots,140,141\}$ that are congruent to 29 modulo 42 are $29, 71, 113$. 

Therefore, the integer $n$ in the set $\{100,101,102,\ldots,140,141\}$ such that $a-b\equiv n\pmod{42}$ is $\boxed{113}$.
solution_prompt:

Therefore, $a-b\equiv 18-73\equiv -55\equiv -55+42 \equiv -13 \equiv 29\pmod{42}$.

So we are looking for an integer $n$ such that $n \equiv 29 \pmod{42}$ and $100 \leq n \leq 141$. 

We can see that the integers in the set $\{100,101,102,\ldots,140,141\}$ that are congruent to 29 modulo 42 are $29, 71, 113$. 

Therefore, the integer $n$ in the set $\{100,101,102,\ldots,140,141\}$ such that $a-b\equiv n\pmod{42}$ is $\boxed{113}$.
